subject: Re: [junit] Unknown Source?
msgSnippet: if you will compile only test src with -g ... you will see at which line failed assert*() resides if you will compile only code src with -g ... you will see at
messageBody:
if you will compile only test src with -g ... you will see at which line
failed assert*() resides
if you will compile only code src with -g ... you will see at which line
exception occurred in your code, if it was not cathced and rethrown in test
case

SO to see which assert fails, you nee -g for test src only

Alexander
----- Original Message -----
From: "Josh Knowles" <josh.knowles@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, June 05, 2002 6:41 PM
Subject: RE: [junit] Unknown Source?


> Are you suppose to turn that on when compiling both the test src and the
> code src or just the test src?
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Mike Clark [mailto:mike@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, June 05, 2002 6:57 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Unknown Source?
>
>
> Guerry Semones wrote:
>
> >I've used Junit in past jobs, and do not recall seeing this
> issue. I am
> >running Junit under JDK1.31 on Windows and a Unix platform. In
> either
> >case, when I get a failure's stack trace, I get "unknown
> source" for my
> >java code, rather than a line number where one would expect it.
> >
>
> Make sure the Java compiler is being invoked with debug enabled
> (-g).
>
> If you're using Ant, the javac task should include
>
> debug="true"
>
>
> Let me know if this helps, and I'll add it to the FAQ.
>
> Mike
>
>
